title: 108_hr1993
content: The "Office of Correctional Health Act of 2003" establishes the Office of Correctional Health under Title XVII of the Public Health Service Act. The Office of Correctional Health, established under the "Office of Correctional Health Act of 2003," is headed by a director appointed by the Secretary of Public Health and Science. The Secretary is responsible for carrying out correctional health activities for individuals in penal or correctional institutions at the federal, state, or local level. Correctional health activities include disease prevention, health promotion, service delivery, research, and health professions education in various types of penal or correctional institutions. These institutions include facilities for individuals pending judicial or administrative proceedings, including minors. In carrying out correctional health activities, the Secretary coordinates programs, provides technical support, cooperates with other agencies, consults with State directors, facilitates information exchange, and promotes collaboration between correctional facilities and health departments. Grants regarding Hepatitis are also provided. The Secretary coordinates correctional health activities, provides technical support, and promotes collaboration between facilities and health departments. Grants for hepatitis screenings, immunizations, and treatment are available to States. Matching funds are required for program costs. The State must provide non-Federal contributions of at least 20 percent of costs for grants, which can be in cash or in kind. Federal contributions or services subsidized by the Federal Government cannot be included in determining the non-Federal contributions. The Secretary may grant funds for activities at penal or correctional institutions, including those not for imprisonment. An annual report on correctional health activities must be submitted to Congress. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out correctional health programs, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2004 through 2008. This section does not require the transfer of jurisdiction for existing programs to the newly established office.
